text: Melanie join McDaniel seems like your
average seven year old playing with your
brother after school it's hard to
imagine that six years ago doctors did
not expect her to live to see her first
birthday Melanie's situation was pretty
hopeless there was nothing good that
they could tell us that to give us any
hope that it would get better before
melanie was one and a half she had
already undergone two major surgeries to
remove a malignant brain tumor but it
had high odds of coming back doctors
offered three different treatment
options one was traditional chemotherapy
the second was to do nothing and the
third option was an untested clinical
trial that offered the family no
guarantees or promises for Melanie's
recovery we knew the two options of the
traditional chemotherapy or just taking
her home and not doing anything we're
kind of guaranteeing her fate was not
going to be good the third option could
have been good could have not been good
but maybe it wouldn't help Melanie but
maybe it would give them more
information to help other children in
her condition
when families are touched with crises
like dying of cancer I have to say that
there is a pretty immediate and striking
kind of reorientation of what's really
important it's really where you see the
best of people that they really begin to
ask not just what's best for me but why
do people go through this this is unfair
what can we do to help not all parents
are willing to take the risks involved
with experimental therapies but so far
the McDaniels brave decision has paid
off the biggest thing I couldn't could
not even imagine watching this child
died that was the constant thing that
was going through my head how am I ever
going to handle watching this child died
this new experimental therapy uses low
doses of several drugs to attack the
blood vessels that feed the tumor
cutting off the supply lines to the
tumor to starve it although Melanie's
treatment was scheduled to last two
years her parents decided to stop her
participation in the trial six months
early toward the end of the year and a
half things got pretty bad with Melanie
and we couldn't figure out if what was
going on with her were symptoms of the
tumor coming back or side effects of the
chemotherapy
so we took her off and that was in may
of 2002 she started to walk she started
to go get her sense of humor and you
know get a lot of activity back and
really started making strides to catch
up with other kids her age we were
always watching out for any kind of
symptoms and it kind of relapse and you
know had that had that every six months
of MRIs and then we had every year and
then two years ago they said well you've
been coming to the brain tumor clinic
for three years now we think that the
next time you come you'll come to the
survivor clinic that we said the
survivor connect yay melanie was not a
home child in the study who seemed to
benefit from the treatment and while
doctors cannot guarantee that Melanie's
tumor will not return for the time being
the McDaniels are enjoying their time
with their daughter
